title: Vinyl Scratch Blind Bag Pony Playset

description.text:
This is the third Playset designed to use MLP Blind Bag figurines. It take about 2.5 hours to print and uses about 41g of plastic with a rift and at 50% infill. This was designed in Inventor Fusion 2013 and was printed on a TOM. It has been broken into several part to be able to be printed on most any printer and to save time in prototyping.
This Playset is Vinyl Scratch's (DJ PON3's) DJ setup from A Canterlot Wedding - Part 2 of My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic.
My Little Pony is the copyright of Hasbro.

Print one of each of the following:
  • Turntable
  • Stand
    • Print two of each of the following:
  • Speaker
  • Arm
    • To Build:
  • Print Parts
  • Place (and I recommend glue) the Turntable to the Stand. Stand should be narrow at the bottom and widen towards the Turntable.
  • Place the one printed Arms in each of the two holes in the Turntable (do not glue if you want them turnable).
  • Enjoy

description.text:
My own designed Duplo-compatible steam locomotive.

Parts

1x chassis
1x cabin
1x steam generator
4x small wheel
2x (4x) big wheel
2x big wheel with axis (still under construction)
2x piston rod (still under construction)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.35

Infill:

10% rectilinear

Notes:

steam generator:

  • resolution: 0.35 verticals, 0.10-0.15 arcs
  • supports: No

chassis:

  • resolution: 0.2
  • supports: No

cabin:

  • resolution: 0.2
  • supports: Yes (its quite difficult to remove it)

Wheels

How the wheel fits on the axis depends on printing resolution of both wheel and axis. If the wheel cannot be pushed on axis or is not rotating freely expand the hole with small file.

Note: This system of axis and wheel works pretty good for wider automobile wheels; train wheels are too narrow so it will never move really smoothly.

title: E3d V6 1.75mm Bowden hotend Bracket for MK2 short travel (there is newer version now holes for left or right)

description.text:
This is a bracket for upgrading the hot end/extruder on a RepRap printer to the E3D V6 hot end and the Bowden style Extruder.

Improved xtra beefy E3d hotend + MK drive extruder short distance bowden mount.
I printed https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1637243 from Arron_mollet22 but found it too thin and break eazy, and the mounting holes where not in the right place.
Ive drawn an improved version in solidworks, main bracket and added a clamp.

A full instuctable is at:

http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printer-ExtruderHot-End-Upgrade/

Printer:

K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm layer height and nozzle

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Ive added G code made with Cura, finetuned for K8200 with 0.4mm nozzle and PLA.
There is support wich breaks off eazy, print time is 2.3hours.
Brim is set to 15mm and part is rotated 45° around Y axis.
Heatbed temperature is 50%, parts cooling fan must be on for good print.
The holes might need to be drilled once, dont drill the mount holes of the main part,
tap them with a M6 tap.
My steps per mm for the original velleman extruder are set to 625 per mm, sightly overextruding for super layer adhesion.

title: CTC i3 MK8 radial fan holder (for MK10 extruder)

description.text:
Prusa type radial fan (50mm) holder for MK10 extruder. Doesn't require additional HW (bolts or nuts)
Chassis will be fasten with the extruder fan bolt (remove the 10mm nylon pipe). Additional support is given by the edge of aluminum extruder bracket.

Ps. The nozzle is its own unit so different nozzles can be used. .

The fan is connected to the PWM connector (next to 3 Fan ports). Two wire fan is OK, but you'll need 3-pin connector e.g.https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2248965

PS. Thought that people would design different kind of nozzles but seems that the original is good enough :-).

Any way, the three directional nozzle added to cool all sides of the object. This part makes the cooling so powerful that the original hot block insulation is not sufficient. (You might get the Thermal Runaway error and/or get the Nozzle hot enough when the fan is in high power.)

description.text:
Starting a night light for my daughter, and decided to make a princess surround. Thus this .stl - Not to pretty to look at, but hold it up to the light and.... look how it changes. It allows light through and looks amazing.

Give me a shout if you have a request to do a different one

Check out my other designs:
Thing: 2367661 - Snow White
Thing: 2366519 - Ariel
Thing: 2373408 - Belle
Thing: 2380001 - Frame

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Layer 0.1000mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Using Standard White PLA:

S3D Settings
Retraction: 6.5mm (1800mm/min speed)

Layer: 1st:H 120% W 150%
1st layer speed 50%

Temp: Bed: 40
Extruder: 215

Speed: 2600.00 mm/min

I used a raft to ensure that the bottom layer didn't have any lines in (I'm using tape on the bed), as these will show whilst shining light through the print.

There should be no need for post-printing finishing. Although if stringing has occurred remove.

Hold up to the light and see the extra detail not visible on print itself!

Imported an image into Cura (i found that it was best to use a transparent image to ensure that no unwanted background parts would be included) and adjusted its setting to ensure that print would allow light to shine through. Resized the image (to match my requirements - be careful at this stage not to increase the overall thickness, as this will reduce the light pass through). I'm sure at this stage Cura would be able to print the file, however i saved it as an .obj and exported it to S3D (preferred software). Then printed

A fan bracket for the flashforge creator, possibly makerbot and others.
The hook at the top is 6mm wide so will fit on any printer with a less than 6mm wide lip.
I tried printing a similar bracket on my flashforge but due to the 2nd nozzle and how thin the other brackets were it would not print correctly.
I have printed 4 of these to support 2 fans, but you could in theory mount 4 fans if you needed that level of cooling.
Use makerware to create the x3g file to send using a raft and supports, you need the support for the overhang of the lip.

title: Hexapuzzle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The easiest way to print modules in a single perimeter, spiral, but if you cannot get thick enough wall, it is possible to print in multiple perimeters, putting the filling on 0 and the upper layers is also 0.
You can scale maintaining aspect ratio X/Y.
Cut on Z is not necessary - you can just stop printing when the module grows to the desired size.
Ideal for those who don't know what to do with the small pieces of filament or gathering dust idle samples.

As you know, bees are smart and have found the perfect strength and economy of construction material shape - the hexagon. In turn, one quick-witted Englishman in the middle of the 18th century invented the puzzle. I just combined those achievements! :)

Printed from Filamentarno!(R) SBS plastics.
www.filamentarno.ru

print_settings.Notes:: It's important to get the parts as flat as possible, so i would recommend avoiding ABS.

description.text:
This is the first instalment of the Pocket Mechanism Series!

It's quite addictive to play with, and there's a certain beauty in the many moving parts and how they oscillate in time. It's made up of three different parts which are all print-in-place, and require no support. Simply insert the three pellets into their individual tracks on the hub, and press fit the handle onto the three pellets.

I would greatly appreciate a Thingiverse Tip from you as this series took quite a bit of trial and error, effort and time.

https://youtu.be/W6vm472-BOE

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15-25%

Notes:

All parts for this mechanism are intended to be printed in place, with no raft or supports. Resolution and infill shouldn't affect the final outcome, so do as you please and report any issues you have please.

There are many important X ad Y tolerances on these parts, so if you have any issue with things not fitting, please let me know.

It's important to get the parts as flat as possible, so i would recommend avoiding ABS.

title: Hyperlite EVO HD Connex Prosight VTX Mount - very light

description.text:
i made this.

it's a mount of the vtx that holds it by the corners for the intended mounting location. this prevents problems caused by attaching the heatsink to a surface like overheating and excess vibration. I'd add a small slice of .25mm silicone pad (ebay) between the vtx and the top plate to allow it to sit against the plate but not vibrate.

installation is pretty straight forward, print in tpe or tpu

author: hattybin

description.text: mount for pcb based led strip

69 Photoshots around the model of this Cowry (Cowrie) shell picked from the beach.

This model has 180,000+ Mesh Faces, recommended to slow your printer speed to get the most detail out of it (perhaps 40mm-60mm/s for infills and perimeters)

The shell is all rounded on every sides, to print with smooth details. Either:
1) Use dis-solvable filaments as supports
2) Slice the shell into half and glue the 2 pieces together when printed out
3) Use the normal way of using supports/pillars to form an artifical base. (Note that the surface might be rough when the support breaks away, use a 400 gritt sandpaper to sand it down to level)

description.text: Tank 3.0.2v Super Tank
i just wanted to see if i could draw a mesh sphere

Like aliens, fidget spinners have taken over Thingiverse and for that I hate them. So, to finish off these terrible spinner infections, I decided to design the very last spinner ever. It works with 4 AAA batteries as weight, but to give them some additional use, they power six slow fade leds, three on each side. These leds cycle through the available colors repeatedly and create circles that continuously change color. All leds have a series resistor of 150 Ohms. All wiring is inside the housing. Push pins take care of contact with the batteries. Bend the pin towards the hole in the housing and solder the leads. Make sure the caps run free from the wires in the cap opening. If necessary, the caps can fixed with an M3 bolt and nut. Print the two parts twice. Soak the bearing for some time in a solvent to remove grease and dirt.
Now you can finely use your spinner in the dark as well.
Thanks for NOT making one :-).
https://youtu.be/Trj5rMZTLMw

description.text:
I was looking for D.va headphones model and was very impressed by this model by FletcherK. But the thing is (and if you tried to print it) - it isn't ready for printing. Plus you can't add leds like in another headphones on another site.
So, after some editing I made a couple of additions to the model:

  • Much more ready for printing then original. Minimal amount of supports.
  • Cutouts for leds and betteries. It's poorly made, but hey, it's here! First thing to be addressed in next revision.
  • Holes and cutout for 1mm metal rod (I used unbend papeclip) in the headband. Now you can secure headphones with hairpins

I used 2 15mm m3 screws to connect bottom parts with middle. Shorter ones will work too.

Default scale fits head with width of 18 cm (7.1 inch).

Existing problems:

  • Top of "speaker" is too thin on it's nose, where it connects with middle part. Expect holes. Gonna fix it in next revision
  • No holes for buttons turned out more annoying then I expected. Now you need to uncrew bottom cover, turn on leds and screw it back. Not very handy. Will add some holes later.

description.text: Ive promiced my nephew ill make hi a toy, so ive made my favorite toy whin i was a kid. ;)

This is an XY table for accurate drilling of circuit boards and other items. It consists of 4 printed parts, 8 skate bearings, 4 lengths of M8 studding, 20 M8 nuts, a piece of 120x120x5mm perspex or wood and 2 sets of timing belts & pulleys (use something like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1362 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:867)

Have a look at the "xytable.aoi" file included here. This in an Art Of Illusion file that contains the complete construction for this item, move stuff around and see where it all goes! There are plenty of 3D renderings to go with the following instructions, each component is colour coded. Here's the key for identifying components:
Yellow: timing belt pulleys (8mm hole)
Green: M8 studding and nuts
Red: self tapping screws (long enough to pass through whatever top you use)
Dark Grey: Skate bearings (22mm od, 8mm id)
Blue: Printed clamps for top
Pink: Printed Y assembly
Light Grey: Printed X assemply Step by Step
1) Print X assembly (as in XYbottom.stl) and insert skate bearings into the 4 holes (a little epoxy might be needed to secure them)
2) Print Y assembly (XYtop.stl) and insert skate bearings in the large holes (as in step 1) and insert a M8 nut in both the smaller holes in the lower part of the assembly (see 2.jpg)
3) Place Y assembly on top of X assembly and run M8 studding through opposite bearings in the X assembly, threading the studding through the nuts in the Y assembly. Thread on an M8 nut either side of each bearing in the X assembly and tighten (see 3.jpg)
4) Print off 2 clamps (clamp.stl) and insert a M8 nut into each hole (again using epoxy if needed.
5) Run M8 studding through each set of opposite bearings in the Y assembly making sure the clambs are threaded on in the middle and tighten a nut onto either side of each bearing (see 5.jpg)
6) Drill holes on your perspex or wood top to match the positions of the clamps and attach the top to the clamps using 2 self tapping screws (see 6.jpg)
7) Attach pulleys and belts to the end of each piece of studding and hold in place with another M8 nut tighetened on the end (see 7.jpg) Now, when you turn each pulley the belt should move the other pulley in the set and move the table. Each revolution of a pulley will move the table by 1.25mm.

These are intended to replace the stock side-frames for the Spidex Micro quad frame. If you assembled your quad with the main plate upside-down (required for certain motor fitment), this causes propellers to be closer than intended to the side-frame overhangs. Sometimes the props can deflect enough to hit and shatter the props. These replacement pieces are TALLER than the stock pieces, to preserve prop clearance! I have a thicker version on my page which is the version I had printed. See the full frame here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:326062

comments.text: The switch/socket in your image is an illuminated DPST (dual pole, single throw) switch, so the neutral wiring (the grey wire) should also enter the switch, just as the black one does. The only wire that should be connected directly is the PE (Protective Earth), the green one.
comments.author: desrtfx

comments.text: My wiring diagram is for the switch illuminated only when switch is on position. There is other way to have the switch light always on. But I like it this way butter :-)
comments.author: desrtfx

comments.text: No, if you enter the supply from the correct side, the switch will only be illuminated in the ON position. If the light is always on, you have the power source (L) (and consecutively the N as well) on the wrong side of the switch connections.

description.text:
Introduction.

This an easy to use backlash calibration item.

In theory you can print it once and be done with your backlash calibration. In reality you probably want to go through at least two iterations. The further off perfect calibration the printer is, the less precise the reading will be. Print an extra after adjustment just to make sure.

Instruction.

Update for M3D users: It has come to my attention that the new software that is compatible with the Micro+ and Pro tends to print the tower too large. Make sure to print it at 1:1 scale. Correct size: 1.2 x 1.2 x 6 cm.

The instructions are quite complicated and I created a video to help understand them. If you watch it you should come back and read the instructions anyway.
https://youtu.be/NdDdhVzleWc

After printing the tower you need to study it carefully.
The front and back sides of the print displays the backlash for the Y-axis. The left and right sides display the backlash for the X-axis.

When you study one of the sides you will see that in the bottom part the layers with a bulge in the corners are wider than the layers without bulges. Henceforth called bulge-layer and square layer. You can say that the bulge-layers "stick out" from the square layers. And at the top the bulge-layers will be narrower than the square layers. The objective is to find the exact layer where the bulge-layer shifts from being wider to being narrower (the match). Basically you are looking for the spot where the ridges disappear. I use either a needle for probing or a magnifying glass to find the flattest part (the match). It can be pretty hard to find if the print quality isn't perfect.

When you have found the layer where the change happens you can count how far off that axis is from a perfect backlash calibration. If the match is below the center mark you still have backlash. If it is above the center mark your backlash compensation is set too high.

Assuming you are using the 0.02 file your calculation is as follows: Each step away from the center represents 0.02 mm of backlash. So If the match is 5 bulges below the center you need to raise the backlash compensation in the software by 5 x 0.02mm = 0.10 mm. If it is 2 bulges above center you need to reduce backlash compensation by 2 x 0.02mm = -0.04mm.

The fine tune file changes 0.01mm pr step.

But my print doesn't look like that, what do I do?

If a side has too wide bulge-layers all the way up: your backlash is bigger than the range of the object. Raise the compensation by 0.2 - 0.3 mm and print the tower again.

If a side has too narrow bulge-layers all the way up: your backlash compensation is too high for the range of the object. Reduce the compensation by 0.2 - 0.3 mm and print the tower again.

If one side looks like the match is pretty close to the center and the other is further off: Calibrate using the side that is furthest off. Depending on the slicer the backlash of the bulge-layers and square layers may cancel each other out. This can happen on 0, 1 or 2 sides of the object. For me I consistently have to ignore the front side of the print.

Final notes.

I like to finish my calibration by printing a nice cylindrical object to confirm the result. Like this one for example: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2371170

Not all software allows you to adjust backlash compensation. You may just have to tighten some belts or live with it.
If you have a M3D printer you can use this article for instructions in where to adjust it. Of course ignore the rest of the article.
https://printm3d.com/solutions/article.php?id=234

Don't be too ambitious. If you can consistently stay within 0.03 mm from the center, you are well off. Probably 0.05 mm for an older printer.

Printer:

Will work for any cartesian printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100, 200 or 250 um

Infill:

None

Notes:

Each section is 1,0 mm so the layer resolution needs to be divisible by 1000 um in order to print consistently.

If your print is full of cracks and has poor layer bonding you could try lowering the print temperature. Also a print with thicker walls tend to look better.

I use a setting called Hollow Thick Walls.

OpenScad.

Credit: I took inspiration from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2256550 But made my object from scratch and made several things differently.

A smaller version of my Dice organizer and rolling tray that looks like a book when closed. Holds 14 standard sized dice. 12 3mm diameter 1mm depth magnets and a pin for the hinge are required for assembly. The magnets that I have in mind can be found through this link (http://www.ebay.com/itm/252648550997), but anything similar would work and the magnets are only necessary if you really don't want the box to open accidentally. I don't have any particular pin in mind, but the hole is diameter 1/10" and runs the whole length, so just get creative about what to put in there. So long as you either have one pin that runs the whole length or two which are at least more than 3-1/4" in length (one in either end) would give a secure hinge for the lid. A slightly loose fit (but not sloppy) would probably work for best movement. Approximately 8 inches by 5 inches by 2 inches total size.

If anyone prints this, please feel free to post it with pictures and a review of how it worked out.

description.text:
Motor mount for the Bix3 to accommodate for bigger standard motors and props

I designed this mount for a Turnigy Aerodrive SK3 2836 1040kv motor. A Propdrive v2 2836 1400kv also fits and possibly other 2836 motors as well, as long as the mounting plate has a hole distance of 33mm diagonally. With this mount it is able to spin a 9x6 inch prop safely.

Non printed parts
You will need 8 M3 x 10 countersunk screws with corresponding M3 nuts, possibly Nylock, if you have them.

Assembly

  • screw the motor to the mounting plate with the (lock) nuts on top.
  • place the other 4 nuts in the recessed hex shaped holes on the mounting tube part
  • screw the mounting plate with the motor to the mounting tube
  • Cut the foam tube that usually holds the original plastic motor tube roughly at the height where the original motor tube would end.
  • glue in the 3d printed motor mount using CA or epoxy. The protruding plastic "wings" should line up with the recessed parts in the foam

With 30% infill this thing is very robust. I have had a few very bad crashes e.g. with the whole foam part holding the motor breaking off. The mount stayed intact during all of these.

remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

description.text:
Power supply cover and mount for

360 Watt power supply

For my build of the AM8 frame for my Anet A8 i needed to change the screw positions to fit my 360 Watt power supply. Also wanted to make a cover for the cables and mount a power switch with fuse in it. Additionally i made a version for an extra round switch to switch an LED strip.

The printed version in the pictures is my installed version, but this is a beta version of the file i'm sharing. On the pictured version the distance between the cover and power supply was off by 5mm. I since corrected this mistake, so it now sits as it should be.

Printing instructions

  • The mount is printed without supports, flat on its back.
  • The cover needs supports, but this is not much. If you lay the cover flat on its front (the part that has the switch holes) then the back part will be build upward. The supports that are needed are for the front section that houses the mounting holes for the front part.
    The back mounting holes have a chamfer so that this section can be printed without any trouble.

Note: The cover is designed to take up to 2 screws in the back for mounting, but if you want to run wires through the channel you cannot use that mounting hole. (in my case its mounted with one screw in the top position and the middle channel and bottom channel are used to run my wires to the mainboard.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

For the mount plate i used 1.2mm parameters (lines) and 1.2mm top and bottom layers. So 6 layers bottom and 6 layers top. This with a 50% infill for strength.

For the cover i used 1.2mm parameters (lines) and 0.8mm top and bottom layers, So in a ffect 4 top and bottom layers. Further i used a 25% infill for the cover.

title: RENEV Endless Enclosure - 3D Printer/Laser Cutter/Equipment Enclosure (customizable/reconfigurable)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a customizable/reconfigurable heavy duty enclosure that can be used to protect what is on the outside from what is on the inside and vice versa. The configuration possibilities are endless (well almost) and so are the uses.

Recommended Uses:

1) Protect ABS 3D Printers from drafts that cause warpage.
2) Protect people and animals from 3d printing and laser cutting gasses when connected to an adequate exhaust system.
3) Protect fingers and paws from equipment with moving parts.
4) Protect delicate equipment and sensitive instruments from people and pets.
5) Public Display Cases for delicate and valuable items.

Recommended Configurations:

1) Can be easily reconfigured for new uses.
2) Small - 15"W x 15"D x 15"H or 21"H or 31"H or 47"H
3) Medium - 23"W x 23"D x 23"H or 31"H or 47"H
4) Large - 31"W x 31"D x 31"H or 47"H
5) Extra Large - 47"W x 47"D x 47"H
6) Panel sizes can be mixed and matched to suit your needs: Examples: 31"W x 15"D x 15"H; 15"W x 15"D x 47"H; 47"W x 31"D x 23"H; etc.
7) Cut your own 0.25" thick panels to customize.
8) Pre-made 0.25" thick acrylic panels can be purchased on http://renev.biz/category/enclosures/renev-endless-enclosures/

Hardware:

1) 3D Print It Yourself hardware can be found on this page
2) Heavy Duty Aluminum and Steel Hardware can be purchased on http://renev.biz/category/enclosures/renev-endless-enclosures/
3) Door-Edge-Mount Hinges - Brass-Plated Steel - https://www.mcmaster.com/#18455a62/
4) Door-Edge-Mount Hinges - Chrome-Plated Steel - https://www.mcmaster.com/#18455a61/
5) 18-8 Stainless Steel Extra Wide Phillips Rounded Head Screws - 10-24 Thread Size, 1/2" Long - https://www.mcmaster.com/#91770a242/ (used for aluminum machined corner brackets)
6) Torx Rounded Head Thread-Forming Screws for Plastic, 18-8 Stainless Steel, Number 8 Size, 3/4" Long - https://www.mcmaster.com/#96001a326/ - (used for outer 2 screws on 3D printed corner brackets)
7) Torx Rounded Head Thread-Forming Screws for Plastic, 18-8 Stainless Steel, Number 8 Size, 1/2" Long - https://www.mcmaster.com/#96001a322/ - (used for inner 2 screws on 3D printed corner brackets)

Accessory Locator:

1) Push-to-Open Magnetic Latch - https://www.mcmaster.com/#1860a22/=17yufzo
2) Door Lock - https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-8-10mm-Thickness-Double-Sliding/dp/B01IVY6MHQ/
3) Equipment-Cooling Fan Thermostat - https://www.mcmaster.com/#19155k16/

Notes:

1) The bottom center of the enclosure can be removed to allow the enclosure to be lowered down around fixed equipment.
2) The center of the top plate can be opened for an exhaust vent or to thread filament through.
3) Panel material does not block laser light.

description.text: This is not the extruder you're looking for. If you're looking for the extruder referenced in Josef Prusa's i3 design, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24219 A dual version of my compact extruder. The only issue I've had with the design so far is that getting the nozzles to the same height is both critical, and difficult, and requires the addition of shims between the groove mount plate, and the carriage. Unfortunately, I think that the solving the alignment issue may require changing to a "Vertical X" carriage style, so that the point where the extruder is mounted to the carriage is separated from where the hot end is mounted to the extruder.

Vitamins: Extruder bodies
Â Â Â Â 2 Geared stepper motor (Minbea PG35L-D48)
Â Â Â Â 2 Drive wheel (MakerBot MK7 or Arcol 11x5).
Â Â Â Â 2 624 bearing (4x13x5).
Â Â Â Â 4 M3 x 25mm Socket head screws.
Â Â Â Â 8 M3 x 35mm Socket head screws.
Â Â Â Â 2 M4 x 20mm Socket head screws.
Â Â Â Â 12 M3 washers.
Â Â Â Â 12 M3 nuts.
Â Â Â Â 2 M4 nuts. Motor sources:
Â Â Â Â  http://eminebea.com/en/product/rotary/steppingmotor/pm/gearbox/pg35l-d48.shtml
Â Â Â Â  http://allelectronics.com/make-a-store/item/SMT-365/STEPPER-MOTOR-WITH-GEARBOX/1.html (Out of stock.)
Â Â Â Â  http://www.mpja.com/prodinfo.asp?number=18840+MS (Identical to the motor carried by All Electronics, including the vestigial gear.) Drive wheel sources:
Â Â Â Â  http://store.makerbot.com/mk7-drive-gear.html
Â Â Â Â  http://indiegogo.com/mini-hyena (the 11x5 version). If you purchase the motor from all electronics, you'll need a small gear puller or faucet puller to remove the vestigial gear. Vitamins: Carriage
Â Â Â Â 4 igus bushings ( sdp-si.com/eStore/PartDetail.asp?Opener=Group&PartID=64165&GroupID=830 ).
Â Â Â Â 3 M3 x 25mm Socket head screws.
Â Â Â Â 4 M3 x 20mm Socket head screws.
Â Â Â Â 6 M3 washers.
Â Â Â Â 7 M3 nuts.
Â Â Â Â 1 M3 locknut. Print the parts, remove the support membranes and walls (The curved ends of the belt clamps on the carriage are support walls which should be removed). Note: If you previously printed the Ron's Compact Extruder, then you can re-use it - just print xcr.stl (the mirror image of rcx.stl) and rdx_carriage.stl Note: I had to use SFACT to slice the model, because slic3r doesn't generate good toolpaths for many of the bridges, and because it leaves out the support for the belt clamp on the carriage. If you think that you need assembly instructions, refer to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22980 . When assembling onto your printer, it's very important that the height of the nozzles be as close as possible - one nozzle is going to be dragging over your print, while you're printing with the other one. I shimmed one of my nozzles with a couple of thin washers, and a couple of layers of kapton tape, to get it as close as possible to the height of the other nozzle. I intend to further tune it with 1200 grit sandpaper, after a bit of testing.

comments.text: The way that I handled adjusting the extruder heights was by putting them on a see-saw with a servo controlled screw that adjusts them during bed leveling...  Not sure that this is any use as it requires a bit extra hardware (uses dual z-probes) and some software to make it happen; but I thought I would share.
comments.author: thomassmith1969

comments.text: I remember someone had a great idea of mounting sandpaper on the bed, grit up, and sanding the nozzles to the same height.  Perhaps once you have it close, this is the trick you had in mind.
comments.author: NEATman

comments.text: Once I finished repairing the second nozzle (I knew there was a reason it was in the "spare" category), I was able to adjust it to within .05mm of the first, and corrected that by shimming it at one end, with 1 layer of kapton tape.

description.text:
After i discovered the wonderful vertical plotter made by rincey12 and his awesome diy-manual (@ makerblog.at) i decided to make a quite similar design from scratch (and try to improve some known problems by throwing in some bearings).

For the gondola-arms i printed them @100% infill and drilled the small holes (for the cord and the set screws to secure it) afterwards to gain some weight and stability. My whiteboard-markers are ~17mm in diameter, so i used a 20mm aluminium tube as gondola-core and some set screws to be able to use smaller pens (whithout changing the mid-point). Between the bearings i used a printed 0.5mm spacer (some more sizes included).

As i wanted to try it on my already mounted whiteboard, i made some 'front-side' holders for the stepper motors (to quickly screw them to your wall-of-interest). The gears are sized for a roller blind cord with a sphere diameter of 4,5mm and a distance (mid-sphere to mid-sphere) of 12mm.

To finally operate it, i used the fantastic polargraph-code made by Sandy Noble.

Part-list:
5m roller blind cord 4,5/12
2x deep groove ball bearing 6004 2RS 20x42x12 mm
2x stepper motor - NEMA-17 200 steps/rev, 12V 350mA
1x Geekcreit UNO R3 ATmega328P Development Board For Arduino
1x Motor Drive Shield L293D For Arduino
8x set screws M4 (10mm)
1x aluminium tube (20mm outer diameter, 1mm thick)
some M2/M3/M4 screws to secure the motor holders, servo and gears

(all these parts + shipping to germany cost me around 80€ in the end)

Big THX to all previous makers and coders providing awesome ideas/manuals & software, this was/is a very cool project. Happy for questions/remarks if you have some.

Anet A8

No

Yes

100 (motor holders 50)

comments.text:
Hi ;-D
Sry for the late response, i'm not at home atm.
I tried to visualize it on the cad-model for you. Basically i marked the center of the square and drilled towards the middle of the bearing/pen (about half the length of the arm) and then drilled a second hole (90deg to the first) from the bottom-side. Because it blocks the last ball of the cord it has to be shifted a bit to the front. Then i cut a thread into the 2nd one and used a set-screw to hold the cord in place.
I hope that sounds understandable ;-) if not i'm happy to help.

title: MeteoStation printable weather station
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
// UPDATE 4
Removed obsolete files. Updated parts with large flat surfaces to print cleaner. Made compartement for Arduino slightly larger, and easier to remove suport (by tapering walls).
Only print MeteoStation-rainguard.stl if updating a older weatherstation.

// UPDATE 3
Now for better rain proofing and better fastening there is the new files MeteoStation-bottom_v2 and MeteoStation-bottom_v2_ZipTieVersion. These files has a grid of holes to let air troug, but prevent water. If you have allready printed this project, then you can print 4x of the MeteoStation-rainguard(s). Note that the holes are tilted upwards to stop rain poring in. Mount them with the high side inwards.

// UPDATE 2
The firmware code and web config for this project have now been updated. There is also a full Tutorial on configuring, building and using this weatherstation on indilib.org
http://indilib.org/develop/tutorials/177-howto-configure-compile-wire-print-and-assemble-the-induino-meteostation.html

And a dev / debug forum thread
http://indilib.org/forum/general/2265-building-the-induino-meteostation-with-3d-printed-housing.html?limitstart=0

// UPDATE 1
Update to v2.
Plastic glass window is now made smaller to allow for IR sensor to be mounted with a clear view of the sky.
The compartement for the arduino is also made larger for easier install.

// ORIGINAL TEXT

This is the Induino MeteoStation 3d printable weather station.

Arduino project on https://indiduino.wordpress.com/2013/02/02/meteostation/ with component list and more. (I am not the developer of the MeteoStation code, only the printable case). This project is a INDILib weather driver, and can be used standalone (With Linux webserver and indiserver for a web based interface). http://indilib.org/develop/arduino/meteostation.html

Use pictures as assembly guide. Sensors for temperature and humidity goes in the 'wind tunnel' betwean the bottom and middle part. Light sensitive sensors mounts under the acryllic glass.

Use 2mm thick 9x9 cm acryllic 'plexi' glass, that can be worked on with wood tools.

Screws used are all countersunk. 4x 4x50mm, 4x (6x for v2) 4x15mm

Finished product is close to 10 cm^3

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Resolution:

200 - 300 um

Infill:

15 - 20%

Notes:

Support on buildplate only.
Only use support for MeteoStation-middle_vX.stl

Only 2.5m of flexible filament is needed. I tried TPU and Cheeta, both worked well.

Print the MeteoStation-windowTemplate.stl in PLA to aid in cutting / drilling window. (1.5m filament)

For main structure (white parts) use filament suitable for outdoor installation. (I used PETG)

This is a raindrop hitting the pavement frozen in time.  
It was modeled in Blender using the fluids modeler.  Blender's fluids engine tends to impose a square symmetry on things.  The initial drop was spherical, but it manifests a square character when it hits the ground  that you wouldn't expect.  But Blender is free and super easy to use so it rocks.

description.text:
hello ! I am a 16 years old design student in highschool, France, and i give you the files of my lamp model.

This is a modern version of the Famous Industrial lamp, that is entirely made in fablabs thanks to 3d printing.
It is a lamp that you can fold to carry with you in your bag (and everywhere ! ), and as soon as you need some lighting, you just have to deploy the mechanical arm, tighten the G clamp and there you go !
The G clamp allows you to attach your lamp pretty much everywhere, and the ligthing is a led strip rolled along the mechanical arm, it is usually usb powered, so you'll just have to plug it in your PC/battery.

feel free to remix it, just dont forget to give me credits !

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

10%

Notes:

For a clean piece, print supports in PVA.

Wooden parts and bolts

The wooden parts dont need a special shape to fit, you can design them on your own, just make sure that the hole for the bolt is 3 millimeters in diameter.

For the bolt, the diameter is 3 millimeters and the length is 40 to 50 millimeters depending on the thickness of your wooden pieces.

bolts, nuts, wood, and led strips are easy to find in a home improvement store.

how it works
Little hook I custom made to replace another metal one. It has two holes on the back side so they can be tight fit with two pc (like hard disk drive) screws.
Whistle repaired by St0rmingBr4in

Print this with no support. For experimented users :
speed up the bridges speed and slow down global printing speed in order to get the perfect print !

title: PiCam case with movable arm bed carriage plate holder

description.text:
Designed a bracket that could hold my Pi camera to the bed and lead the ribbon cable neatly inside. I designed a arm construction that could move the camera in every place and angle.
The case for the camera is a remix of some older design I found on the web. I changed it so that it had cooling for the IR-led's and made it esthetically more pleasing and functional.

In the pictures you also see a case for mt Raspberry Pi with touchscreen, this is the basic model from #Adafruit but i updated it so the ribbon cable woud come out of the bottom and had a protective piece over it. I also made 2 bracket holders that hold the case to the Wanhao i3 frame.(these models are not on thingiverse yet).

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Notes:

I only used supports for the bracket piece. i did custom supports so that it would not make supports under need the opening for the ribbon cable. other then that there is no special instruction on how to print these.

You do need too have your setting nailed in that your bridging is up to par. ;)
assemble everything with m3 nuts and 20mm bolts plus one that is 10-15mm for inside the rotating arm head.

This is a simple prototyping mount to hold two SparkFun LED Matrix breakout boards. I'm working on a larger LED Matrix setup, but wanted to do some software prototyping using two of the MAX7219 LED controller ICs. Here is the parts list and purchase links: Hardware:
(1) M2.5 Tap
(8) M2.5 x 5mm Machine Screws Electrical:
(2) SparkFun LED Matrix Kit
(4) 0.1" Crimp Connector Housing 1x5
(15) Female Crimp Pins
(5) Male Crimp Pins
(1) Crimping Tool
(N/A) Wire and Wire Strippers
(N/A) Soldering Iron NOTE: You will also need a microcontroller (or anything with Digital Input/Output pins) to interface with the LED Matrix controller ICs. I personally have been using an Arduino.
Just tap the 8 holes with the M2.5 tap, and then screw the LED Matrix PCB's to the mounting plate.

description.text:
Big thanks to profguy and djblingbling1 for providing the source models!

A friend has broken her collarbone (clavicle).
Now she has an implant and is a step closer to wolverine!
I designed this model to remind her of her clumsiness for eternity...

Besides it is a very nice model to teach the actual dimensions of that bone and how it can be repaired.
i used these pics as a template:
http://img.medicalexpo.de/images_me/photo-g/78050-8441318.jpg
http://g01.s.alicdn.com/kf/HTB14rKwPpXXXXcRXVXXq6xXFXXX7/202889687/HTB14rKwPpXXXXcRXVXXq6xXFXXX7.jpg

IMPORTANT:
this is NOT an actual implant / bone replacement for medical use!
so don't sue me, if something goes wrong ;-)

[UPDATE 09.06.2017] - SCREW YOU!!!!!!
thanks to barry99705's idea i added two different screw dummys. they can be printed separately and be glued during assembly.
to differ the size of the screws easily, they are produced in different colors. so if you are using both on the same model, consider using a different colors for each screw (blue and red?).
thanks!

This fan mount will duct a 40mm fan to your bed. Made for a Prusa and mounts to this x-carriage: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23555 One of the images shows the right-side of the bed fan. You can see that the mirrored x-carriage can hold two fans, one for the bed and one for the hot-end. The scad file is attached. Feel free to change and reuse however you want. I'm thinking at some point I may modify it with some mounts for LEDs to make viewing the printing part easier.

Print the fan mount and donut, then bolt together using two M3x8mm bolts and nuts.  Mount to the linked carriage above, with the donut around your extruder.  If the donut sits too low, print one or more spacers and put between carrige and fan mount to raise it up some (2mm per spacer).

comments.text: Mine broke but I don't have the best 3d printer..
comments.author: Spidor

comments.text:
yeah, i took the plunge and tried too. used 5 shells and 100% fill, support.
the support destroys the finish on the underside because so much is needed. the bearing openings are just a little too large, so the bearings either need to be glued in or it needs to be printed at about 97% size, but that gets back to putting the bearings in again.
freezing the bearings to make them smaller would make them easier to put in if the print were scaled down, but as it stands, they slide through if too much pressure is put on them, which is likely if you're spinning it. the slightly too large opening also means that the bearings don't rest completely flush, causing an eccentricity when you spin it, and the two bearings opposite each other are not going to have the same amount and direction of wobble.
this is one of those models posted so that someone could say "woah, yeah, i'm creative, look what i designed!" but turns out to be impractical to properly print, or to use if you do manage to print it. as usual, if there's no photo of an actual print from the original poster, beware.
i'll post an "i made one." i suggest anyone else that has given it a try, successful or otherwise, do so as well. so far, there's zero, and that's not enough.
comments.author: MeisnerX

comments.text:
I looked at the model in OpenSCAD and checked the bearing openings against 22mm cylinder. I found that x0.995 scale factor is enough to make them exactly 22mm.
You may either check the bearings diameter (just in case), or check your 3D printer firmware configuration for stepper motor steps per milimeter. E.g. in Marlin for Arduino (Configuration.h):

author: sebjsp

description.text:
It was time to clean up the cables going to my extruder and hot end.  This uses the existing bolt locations on the Y axis, and tie-wraps to the back of the Printrboard frame.  The cable is allowed to move in all three axis, so alignment is not critical. I have been running mine for several weeks and it has performed very nicely.  
Included you will find my usual documentation.  This also includes all the electrical connectors in case you need to extend any cables. The Ubis hot end cable needs extending if you are to run it inside the track, but I have listed  all electrical connectors in the event they are needed.  
I borrowed the basic cable chain from RotoScan, cleaned it up to print better for me, and added a slot in the back to allow a cable to be inserted from the back.  This way I can add or remove a wire without trying to fish it all the way down the track.   
Feedback, good or bad, is always appreciated and encouraged.  
Enjoy.  
2014-4-5 RevA: Updated base mount to clear a collision when Y axis is completely retracted. "BaseMountRevA.STL"

description.text:
This fidget spinner is engineered to give the greatest moment of inertia possible. Read the "How I Designed This" section for more information.

My own build uses steel weights to weigh in at 10oz (283g) but if you have the money for tungsten it would be around 19oz (539g) and >$90 in weights. Even with the steel weights I have not been able to find another spinner with greater mass.

After hand spinning, I timed a spin at 4m 10s with a hybrid bearing.

Hardware & weight:
35x 1/4oz (3/8"dia x 1/2"h) steel cylinder pinewood derby car weights OR 1/2oz tungsten weights
1x 608 bearing of choice
8x M3x16mm bolt
8x M3 nut

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro C

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed in MeltInk Red PLA

The first few inner walls for the bolt/nut holes will not be supported. But it is so close to the bed, that it builds its own support quickly. I was always able to cut those first loops out, leaving a somewhat level surface. It is the edges of the holes that are important. They will be sandwiched against the weights.

I set out to build a fidget spinner with the greatest moment of inertia possible. For a thin cylindrical shell I = mr^2. Increasing the radius of weight would be the most effective, but it wouldn't be a fidget spinner if you can't hold it in your hands. So r is limited to the typical 3" radius. The next best thing is to locate as much mass (weight) as close to the outer edge as possible.

Going down the list of densest metals, platinum and plutonium were out of the question. Searching for tungsten weights, I found a 'standard' sized weight, 3/8" diameter x 1/2" height, normally used for pinewood derby cars. They are available in both tungsten ($$) and steel.

As i started to design around this weight size I concluded that I could fit 21 weights along the standard 3" radius for fidget spinners. Another 15 could fit one diameter inside that. The cheapest tungsten I could find was ~$2.50 per 1/2oz weight. I'm not ready to buy $90+ in weight so I chose 36 steel weights (~$16). Tungsten weights would have totalled 18oz (510g), and steel is half that at 9oz (255g). My final design dropped 1 weight so that it was a repeatable pattern as 7 groups of 5 weights.

description.text:
This is a fidget spinner with the capability to use a string to impart additional spinning speed. Fishing weights in the lobes are used instead of bearings. The combination of additional weight and greater initial speed results in extra long spin duration.

Fishing string is used to impart the spin. Tie a knot at one end to catch on a notch built between each of the lobes and wind the string around a ring on top of the fidget. Using a 16 in. string will result in 5 turns around the hub. This gives excellent initial speed. A longer string will make the spin last even longer.

Each cap has a pair of tabs that slide into the tabs of the other cap.

A standard 608ZZ Shielded 8x22x7 Miniature Ball Bearing is used in the center.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Used 0.6 mm nozzle.

3mm ABS filament was used.

Fitting the weights and string

This fidget is designed for barrel shaped fishing weights that are about 16 mm long and 14 mm in the belly. They way about 16 grams.

I used 30-lbs. test fishing line with a know on one end and a loop at the other for the spinning string.

If you have trouble inserting the weights or the bearings, you can use a heat gun to warm the plastic to just before it begins to deform.

Like a Top

A friend said that the fidget spinner is like a top was in the past. That gave me the idea of using a string to initiate the spinning action. The string makes the fidget spin like a top.

description.text:
The long-running BBC children's television programme Blue Peter has a series of badges they give to exceptional people who contact or appear on the show.

Now, you can make your own badge inspired by the classic Blue Peter badge. This shape has been made to exactly match the measurements of a 1980s-era Blue Peter badge I own (shown in the attached photos). The sailing-ship motif on the flat front of the real badge is not present on this model; you are free to add your own design inspired by the show's logo, or something else entirely.

No pin is provided on the back of this model; you can get one to glue on from a craft shop, or reuse a pinback from another small badge.

PLEASE NOTE: This is not intended as a fake or counterfeit Blue Peter badge for fraudulently obtaining the benefits of a genuine badge! It won't work as one, anyway; children who earn a genuine Blue Peter badge get a photo ID they need to also show to gain the badgeholders' benefits, and the current-day badges have a slightly-different shape and sculpted details not present on this model. This model is only intended as a little old-school pop-culture-inspired accesory for modern-day nostalgics, costumers and cosplayers (classic Doctor Who companion Ace wore two of these on her jacket!), and anyone else who can have some harmless fun with the idea.

In addition to sharing this file freely here, I've made pro-grade prints available in a variety of plastic and metal materials here on my Shapeways shop. If you wish to go the route of buying a print, buying it from there would be very cool of you. The above photos of prints are done in Shapeways' White Polished and Blue Polished nylon.

This is a 3-D printed holder for your apple tv box. There are two small holes on either side of the box, visible in the pictures, and you can use to screw nails throw so that your apple tv will stay to the wall. I did make one error that is depicted in the picture where you can not use the last plug, fortunately for my purposed that plug is not needed but make sure that you don't need it either before printing this product.

author: sebjsp

description.text:
This is a case for a Kitronics FM Radio (v2.0).
The main box contains posts in each corner so the board can go in upside down to protect the components.
It is easier to attach the volume/tuning controls via longer wires (rather than soldering directly to the board) to make it easier to assemble.
We glued the speaker to the front wall and then glued the speaker grill on the front. The grill could have been designed as part of the front face, but we thought this might have made it more difficult to assemble.

Main box and lid used standard print settings, but we used higher fill (80%) and slower speed for the grill.

title: Die Kolonisten Sortierung - The Colonists Storage (incl. Add-On Ante Portas)

description.text:
Hallo zusammen,

ich hatte leider das Update zu der Box_Figuren vergessen. Aufgrund der Aufteilung hatte ich das beim Hochladen übersehen.

Hier die Auflistung was Ihr alles drucken müsst:

1x Box_Epoche_V2 (1x Box_Epoche_V2_Part_1 / 1x Box_Epoche_V2_Part_2)
1x Box_Rohstoffe (1x Box_Rohstoffe_Part_1 / 1x Box_Rohstoffe_Part_2)
1x Box_Figuren_V2 (1x Box_Figuren_V2_Part_1 / 1x Box_Figuren_V2_Part_2)
1x Box_Lager (1x Box_Lager_Part_1 / 1x Box_Lager_Part_2)
4x Box_Gebaeude (4x Box_Gebaeude _Part_1 / 4x Box_Gebaeude_Part_2)
4x Box_Karten (4x Box_Karten_Part_1 / 4x Box_Karten_Part_2)

1x Box_Szenario_1
1x Box_Szenario_2 (1x Box_Szenario_2_Part_1 / 1x Box_Szenario_2_Part_2)
1x Box_Szenario_3

Update!

Hallo zusammen,

pünktlich vor Weihnachten habe ich das Szenario "Ante Portas" mit integriert, sodass es auch in die Verpackung verstaut werde kann.

Was ist neu?

Die Epoche bekommt eine Version 2 und lässt sich nun stapeln. Die Box_Figuren wurde aufgefrischt und erhält mit der Erweiterung einen Einsatz, den man rausnehmen kann. Da das Szenario "Ante Portas" relativ umfangreich ist, waren zwei neue epochenähnliche Boxen notwendig.

Die Karten kann man in den aktuellen Kartenstapeln mit verstauen. Da die Anfrage kam, habe ich alle größeren Modelle geteilt.

Viel Spaß weiterhin beim spielen!

.
.
.
.
Hallo zusammen,

ein umfangreiches Spiel kann einen oftmals die Lust rauben, da der Zeitaufwand für das Aufbauen länger dauert als das Spiel selbst...

Gut, das mag übertrieben klingen. Aber jeder Vielspieler weiß, wovon ich rede. Leider gibt es aktuell noch keine Sortierboxen für das Spiel "Kolonisten", wodurch ein Aufbau und das Ordnen der gefühlt tausenden Plättchen sehr nervig sein kann.

Da das Spiel viel Spaß macht, sollte die Vorfreude nicht schon beim Auspacken verloren gehen.

Ich habe alles so konstruiert, dass man die Boxen in der Verpackung stapeln kann. Eine kleine Tüte ist übrig geblieben, was jedoch zu verkraften ist.

Der Support ist für die Kante zum Aufeinanderstapeln notwendig und nimmt nicht viel Volumen ein. Ich habe mit 0,3 mm gedruckt. Aber natürlich geht es auch feiner.

Damit alles passt müsst Ihr von den Boxen folgende Anzahl drucken:

1x Box_Epoche
1x Box_Rohstoffe
1x Box_Figuren
1x Box_Lager
4x Box_Gebaeude
4x Box_Karten

Ein großes Lob an den Autor des Spiels: Tim Puls. Ich hoffe, dass noch ein paar Epochen rauskommen, um eine noch längere Session durch die Zeit starten zu können.

Viel Spaß beim spielen!

print_settings.Notes:: Printer on a glass with a hair spray.

description.text:
Specs:

  • "double" focusing mechanism for both lens and film frames with anti backlash
  • smooth movements on double 8mm rod rail using SC8UU linear ball bearings
  • back frame - fixed in z-axis, +-10 degrees tilt
  • front frame - moved in all directions
  • uses standard 4x5 film holders
  • 162x162 lens board (Cambo size).
  • 162x162 bellows frame (Cambo size, may be adapted to 158x158 toyo).
  • uses 1/4-20 bolts and nuts
  • uses metal paper clips to fix lens board, bellows and back.

BlackRiverViewCamera4x5v1.0.zip file all contains DesignSpark Mechanical sources, stl & obj files.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printer on a glass with a hair spray.

Update Feb 8, 2018.

Published new / updated files.

BOM

  • 16 x 1/4-20 nuts
  • 2 x 1/4-20 lock nuts (for focusing knobs)
  • 4 x 1/4-20 1" bolts (hold base together)
  • 8 x 1/4-20 1 1/2" bolts (for knobs)
  • 2 x 1/4-20 5-8" bolts (for focusing)
  • 2 x 8mm rods (at least 5" long)
  • 4 x SC8UU with bolts
  • 4 x 1" compression springs that will fit over 1/4" bolt
  • 4 x 1" springs for ground glass frame
  • 4x 1/4" washers
  • 1 x 4x5" ground glass - I did mating myself using glass from the 4x6 picture frame.
  • 12 x metal clips
  • 1 x 1/4 20 insert nut (nut sert, about 9mm in diameter) for the tripod mount
Update Feb 11, 2018
  • Added "70mm-Shorter-Adapter" - pushes front frame up to 70mm back to be able to accept wider lenses. You will need 2 of these.
Printing & Assembly

First of all print Square-Check-180x180.obj to ensure your printer is properly squared properly. Please measure while part still on a bed. Must be 180x180mm, 254.558mm both diagonals.

I printed it in black PLA, 0.2mm, 3 perimeters, 30% infill on all parts. 1mm top / bottom.

Both frames require supports in order to print properly - during assembly make sure that "support" bottom sides facing bellows.

IMPORTANT - distance between ground glass and back frame must be exactly 5mm. I used sticky paper to adjust. This is the distance from the frame the film

Assembly Photo Gallery:
https://photos.app.goo.gl/2sKqeYWhB5nqSPrE2

Parts Links
Springs: https://www.harborfreight.com/200-piece-assorted-spring-set-67562.html
Ground glass abrasive: https://www.harborfreight.com/rock-polishing-abrasives-30956.html

TODO
  • Improve focusing - it works, but is not very smooth
  • Improve focusing knobs usability by adding handle?
  • Custom front plates for different lenses

comments.text: Fantastic job! I´ve been looking for a 3d printable real large format camera for quite a while now, but all I have found are pinhole or very simple fixed focus designs, not really suitable for any serious work.  I´m really looking forward to see your results with this project! Do think your design might be adoptable for even larger sizes like 5x7 or even 8x10 when using a large printer? I suppose the most critical dimensions are the parts around the film holders and maybe the lens mount, most other parts could probably be just scaled up to the right size?  :)
comments.author: E-Mat

comments.text:
Hello,
Thank you for the comment. I actually finished my first prototype. I will be reprinting all parts again to ensure everything fits and then will republish files (my printer was not squared well when I printed it first time, so I added extra gaps where they were not needed).. I do not see any reasons why it cannot be scaled to the larger format. Not sure you will be able to scale it "directly" while printing in cura or so... I guess the best way will be to redesign it to fit the size.
comments.author: E-Mat

comments.text: Yes that was my idea. no need to completely re-design all parts, but use the same basic structure and adjust dimensions for a larger film size. What kind of film back are you using? It should be possible to make a 3D printed spring back as well.
comments.author: vfalendysh

comments.text: Oh, wow, that looked awesome! I've always wanted to try my hands at medium format (edited: I meant large format). One question about this print: the metal rod clamp/holder, are those built in-house (do I need to go have them built) or could I get something like that from online stores (did you buy them from somewhere)?
comments.author: olav216

comments.text:
Metal rods - please check ebay/amazon/etc for the 8mm hardened steel linear bearing rod - they are commonly used in the 3d printer builds.
Linear motion ball bearings - look for SC8UU. These are standard and used in 3d printers / CNC builds as well. I use 4 of them (will also need M4 metric bolts for them). Focusing "rods" - these actually 4" 1/4x20 bolts. You can use threaded 1/4 rods as well, just need lock nut on one of the ends.
comments.author: olav216

comments.text: Great idea to re-purpose the printer rods and linear motion ball bearings to this. Thanks for the additional information. I'll reserve any further questions until your BOM and finalized design (v1.0?). I'm looking forward to seeing updates on this one.

title: 9V Battery Tray Adapter for LR Baggs Para-DI (and others)

description.text:
Some audio stomp boxes use a 9V battery tray that makes it tricky to adapt to wall power. The LR Baggs Para Acoustic DI uses the battery tray and doesn't have the typical 5.5mmx2.1mm power plug.

I considered hacking in the power connector, but decided instead to 3D print an adapter with the same dimensions as the battery tray so I can use the pedal with wall power and without modifying the pedal.

Source files included for FreeCad (0.16).

Assembly notes

  • the little wedge on the bottom keeps the tray from sliding out.. this is somewhat optional (mine was a pretty snug fit without it) and you might have to tweak your printer parameters a bit to get this to work. Mind the direction of the wedge, the point is to keep the tray in.

  • The power jack is a Radio Shack 2741563 but any similar 5.5 x 2.1mm coaxial power jack should work (7/16" hole). Good luck finding a Radio Shack, nowadays.

  • I had to enlarge the wire holes slightly. Light gauge solid wire is probably easiest to work with (20 or 22 ga). I used stranded wire, but pre-soldered it.

  • Be aware of the polarity of your device! Most 9V stomp boxes use a center-negative power connector (Thanks, Boss/Roland). Getting the polarity wrong could toast your precious pedal. Use a volt-meter and check the polarity while connected to the power adapter before powering up the pedal!
The high part of the wedge is near the little handle/front of the tray Soldering required. Note: negative on the left, positive on the right terminal in this pic. If you're soldering-challenged then you might redesign the part to work with one of these screw-terminal adapters.

Design Notes

  • Measured the existing battery tray and power connector with digital calipers

  • Designed in FreeCAD (Why doesn't Thingiverse list FreeCAD in their standard list of programs?)

  • Went through the print/test/tweak-design cycle a few times until it was right

*** Edit 6/8/2017 - NOTE: If you want the better, separate, easier-to-print version of this Thing, please visit the new "Separate" version here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2373387

Does the world need another headphone holder, desk clip, thing...?

Apparently, yes.

I own the Bose QC35 noise-canceling headphones. They're pretty, and soft, and work great. But whenever I'd use any of the multitude of headphone clips on Thingiverse, they were all about 25mm wide, which looks great, and works well for less-comfortable headphones with headbands that hard plastic won't leave an impression on, but these Bose headphones have a soft headband cushion in the top, which is pliable, impressionable, and they clearly need more surface area to avoid a weird, ugly, 25mm divot in the center of your fancy gear.

So I fired up Fusion 360, grabbed my shelf-clip bracket (which fits great on my 25mm thick desk/hutch top), and created a new project: the one-piece Bose QC35 Headphone Holder. I fiddled with geometry, and fillets, tried to get things to look nice, but also fit the headphones well. I took a picture, measured the headband, created a curve in the software that mimics the curve of the headphones, extruded, softened things up with a torus, and then made some more fillets. Oh, and earlier, I created a hook on the back, because you never can tell when you're going to need a hook to hold stuff behind your headphones. Or a shiv to stab someone trying to invade your home! Nah, I checked it out, there aren't many stabby edges on this item, because I love fillets because I love curves. If you want a slightly more pointy design for home safety, just let me know!

So yeah, a hook, curves all over the place, fits my desk (at least on paper) perfectly well and then....

To quote Gob (GOB? G.O.B.?) from Arrested Development:

"I've made a huge mistake."

I designed this headphone hook with awesomeness in mind. I was super excited when I finished making it, and it looked so pretty, but there's literally no way to make this design sit flat on the bed, so you need a lot (like 50% of the time and filament in this was supports!) of overhead to get this to work. It's like 4 hours versus 2 hours. Maybe you can figure out a better way? My better way - and the next version I'll be posting once I've printed it out and tested the "fit" of the components - is the two-piece slide-together model. Same exact geometry as this fella, but with a slide-mechanism kinda like a camera hotshoe, which holds everything together. And gravity should keep it snug. If that doesn't work, you can always use glue. But that's the next version. The best part about the new version is that it prints in two pieces, flat on the bed, and fits in one go on my Flashforge Creator Pro.

This version is one piece, so four hours and a heck of a lotta support structure later, you've got this thing that will safely hang your Bose QC35 headphones without "pinching" the soft headband layer.

So, if you love wasting time and filament on support structures, sanding, and finishing, this is the version for you! (Masochist!)

If you want something easier, you'll want to wait for the two-piece model. Trust me, it'll be just as awesome, waste less time and plastic, and it'll have this cool slidy thing! I'll probably have it posted in a few days, or today, who knows?

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

With the way I designed this all-in-one headphone holder, you really have no choice but to use supports. Sorry! The next version will be two separate pieces, which will slide together, and will not require as many supports. I'm just learning, so hopefully this works for you, and it isn't too hard to clean-up the supports your software generates.

How to Assemble

Ha! Tricked you. There is no assembly. There's just a crap-ton of cleaning, removing support structures, and sanding if you have weird connective surfaces. I did!

Please be careful working with support structures. I've cut myself on the thin "accordion" layers of plastic. They can be sharp! Use gloves or, if you just don't care, raise your hands in the air (or don't), and work without gloves. Or leave the support structures intact, in situ, and use this hook as a modern art sculpture - in plastic.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

Fusion 360 rocks! I created this holder/hook in a day, and it works great. My headphones are happy, but honestly, aesthetically, I'm probably going to toss this one-piece as soon as the two-piece model is ready. They should look very similar (identical?), except the two-piece should be cleaner, as it'll have fewer support structure artifacts.

Simplify3D created the support structures, which were easy to remove but...yeah. Not perfect. Looking forward to the two-piece, because fitting things into other things is what life is all about.

author: hollerer

description.text: Holds three 2oz Mercury Adhesive Bottles and one bottle of accelerator.  Hollow base reduces filament needed.

Printed at 0.3mm in PLA on Mendel90.  I printed it upside down so that the top surface of the finished part would be smooth and flat.  I did have problems with the large/long bridges on the bottom of the bottle cavities sagging.  I fixed it by warming the sagged portion with hot air and pressing them flat.  Adding break-away support pillars would have prevented this.  Alternatively could have left the cavities open and printed separate caps that glue on the cavity bottoms.

Infil 20%
Modell shells 4-6

This is a model of San Francisco Bay showing the terrain above water and the contours underwater. It is based on the best available (at least to civilians) DEM and topobathy (dig that word) data. The elevations both above and below water are exaggerated 4x to make it an interesting print. I also did a simple model of the bridges which will print at that scale. If you insist it be anatomically correct check out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:237164 This is a dual extruder model split at sea level. If anyone wants a single extruder version ask and I will post.
